{{Use Indian English|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox military person |name=Darwan Singh Negi |image=File:Illustrated War News, Dec. 23, 1914, page 38, left side - Darwan Sing Negi.jpg |caption=Image from ''[[The Illustrated War News]]'' of December 23, 1914 showing the injured Negi being carried into the [[Royal Pavilion]], [[Brighton]] then in use as a hospital for wounded troops. |birth_date={{birth date|1881|11||df=y}} |death_date={{death date and age|1950|6|24|1881|11||df=y}} |birth_place=Karbartir, [[Uttarakhand]], India |death_place=Kafarteer |burial_place= |allegiance=[[British Raj|British India]] |branch=[[British Indian Army]] |serviceyears= |rank=[[Subedar]] |unit=[[39th Garhwal Rifles]] |commands= |battles=World War I |awards=[[File:Victoria Cross (UK) ribbon.png|30px]] [[Victoria Cross]] |relations= |laterwork= }} '''Darwan Singh Negi''' [[Victoria Cross|VC]] (November 1881{{snd}}24 June 1950) was among the earliest [[British Raj|Indian]] recipients of the [[Victoria Cross]] (VC), the highest and most prestigious award for gallantry in the face of the enemy that can be awarded to [[United Kingdom|British]] and [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]] forces.
Negi was approximately 33 years old, and a [[Naik (military rank)|naik]] (equivalent to [[corporal]]) in the 1st Battalion, [[39th Garhwal Rifles]], [[British Indian Army]] during the First World War when he performed the deeds during the [[Defence of Festubert]] for which he was awarded the VC. The citation reads:
{{quote|[[George V|His Majesty the KING-EMPEROR]] has been graciously pleased to approve of the grant of the Victoria Cross to the undermentioned soldier of the Indian Army for conspicuous bravery whilst serving with the Indian Army Corps, British Expeditionary Force: â€”
1909, Naik Darwan Sing{{sic}}<!--DO NOT CHANGE, that is how it reads in the original--> Negi, 1st Battalion, 39th Garhwal Rifles.
For great gallantry on the night of the 23rd{{ndash}}24th November, near [[Festubert]], France, when the regiment was engaged in retaking and clearing the enemy out of our trenches, and, although wounded in two places in the head, and also in the arm, being one of the first to push round each successive [[Traverse (trench warfare)|traverse]], in the face of severe fire from bombs and rifles at the closest range. |London Gazette, 7 December 1914.<ref>{{LondonGazette |issue=28999 |supp=yes |startpage=10425 |date=7 December 1914 |accessdate=1 November 2014}}</ref>}}
He was awarded the medal on the same day as [[Khudadad Khan]] VC; but the latter's VC action was of earlier date, so that he is regarded as the first Indian recipient.
He retired with the rank of [[subedar]], the rank equivalent to a British lieutenant.
His Victoria Cross is held by his family. The regimental museum of [[The Garhwal Rifles]] in [[Lansdowne (town)|Lansdowne]], [[Uttarakhand]] is named the Darwan Singh Museum in his honour.
